in the city traffic schedule are designated as truck routes    truck traffic from outside city  deviation by shortest permissible route a single destination all trucks entering the city for a destination point in the city shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street upon which such traffic is permitted nearest to the destination point upon leaving the destination point a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route b multiple destinations all trucks entering the city for multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street upon which such traffic is permitted nearest to the first destination point upon leaving the first destination point a deviating truck shall proceed to other destination points by the shortest direction and only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted upon leaving the last destination point a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route    truck traffic from within city a destinationsoutside city all trucks on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for a destination point outside the city shall proceed by the shortest direction over streets on which such traffic is permitted to a truck route b samewithin city all trucks on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for destination points in the city shall proceed from the point of origin to the nearest established truck route and over the established truck route to the point thereon nearest the point of destination thence from the point on the truck route nearest the point of destination by the shortest route to the point of destination all trucks leaving a first point of destination in the city to another point in the city shall proceed to the nearest established truck route thence over the truck route to the point nearest the second or latter destination point thence by the shortest possible route to the point    maintenance of maps the city clerk and treasurer shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck routes and streets upon which truck traffic is established and designated as truck routes the maps shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and treasurer and shall be available for inspection by the public    maintenance of signs the chief of police shall cause all truck routes to be clearly marked by appropriate signs it shall not be a legal defense for violation of this article that the truck routes have not been marked with such clearness as to give warning to any person charged with such violation    enforcement  duty of police officers it shall be the duty of police officers on duty observing a motor truck on a street in the city other than on an established truck route to stop the truck and inspect the bill of lading invoice or other papers to determine that the truck is being operated on streets as required by the terms of this article    presumption of intercity passage any person driving a motor truck over any street in the city other than a designated truck route shall be presumed to be passing city and not making a local delivery and unless the driver has a bill of lading or invoice showing a local delivery it shall be the duty of any police officer apprehending such truck driver to arrest him for violation of this article    secs 106335106360  reserved article vii  traffic calming devices policy this article establishes a policy for the installation of traffic calming devices and establishes certain warranting criteria to be used to determine whether a traffic calming device may be installed along a roadway in the city  622009 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning traffic calming devices means any device installed in the roadway designed to limit vehicle operating speeds and to encourage vehicles to seek alternative routes including but not limited to the following rumble strips means a series of small raised pavement undulations often seen on the approaches to intersections on high speed roadways the rumble strip is a series of five to seven raised pavement areas each being eight inches wide and onehalf inch high spaced on ten inch gaps speed bumps  also referred to as a speed breaker means a raised pavement section typically less than one foot wide and three to four inches in height typically found in commercial parking lots and driveways the design of speed bumps generally makes them inappropriate for use on the public rightofway speed humps means a raised pavement section approximately 12 to 14 feet long and three inches high speed humps typically have the cross section of a section of an arc of a circle and extend from edge of asphalt paving to edge of asphalt paving on the roadway without obstructing the gutter using a 12inch taper to the gutter seam typical materials for the construction of a spend hump are asphalt concrete rubber and brick speed lumps  also known as speed cushions are a variation of speed humps instead of a continuous hump it is divided into several smaller sections which allows for unobstructed passage of emergency vehicles buses trucks and other wide wheelbase vehicles and allows for improved drainage the gaps are spaced such that only one set of standard vehicle tires will go gap while the other set of vehicle tires must go over the hump speed tables means devices similar to speed humps except that the overall length of the table is extended to approximately 22 feet which allows for a ten to 12foot flat area on top of the speed hump this flat area is sometimes used as an area for pedestrian crossing and is known as a raised crosswalk  622009 approval required prior to installation  traffic calming study and criteria no traffic calming device shall be installed along a roadway in the city without the prior approval of the city council prior to the installation of a traffic calming device upon any roadway in the city there shall be conducted a traffic calming study which may or may not recommend the installation of a traffic calming device based upon the following warranting criteria 1 traffic volume criteria traffic calming devices will not be considered for roadways which have less than 750 total vehicles traveling in both directions on a daily basis nor more than 7500 total vehicles traveling in both directions on a daily basis 2 speed criteria traffic calming devices will not be considered unless the average travel speed of all vehicles observed is equal to or greater than 35 miles per hour or the 85th percentile travel speeds of all vehicles is equal to or greater than 40 miles per hour 3 roadway classification criteria traffic calming devices will not be installed on roadways which are classified as a federal aid route according to the current roadway classification map for the birmingham study area as held by the regional planning commission of greater birmingham traffic calming devices will not be installed on roadways which are classified in the citys major street plan 4 roadway geometric criteria traffic calming devices will not be installed in the following roadway geometric conditions a a horizontal curve or a vertical curve where the visibility of the traffic calming device is restricted or on an approach to such curves  b on roadways at any location where the grade exceeds five percent including the approaches to each traffic calming device installation  c on roadways more than two lanes wide or less than 18 feet wide  d on roadways having a posted speed limit of greater than 30 miles per hour  e on roadways that have a curb and cutter or valley gutter on both sides of the roadway  or f where placement of traffic calming devices are impractical due to the location of the public roadway intersections andor driveways 5 accident criteria accident patterns shall be studied to determine trends of accidents which a might have been prevented if vehicle operating speeds were generally lower on the subject roadway  or b might have been more severe if traffic calming devices were in place there are no criteria for the minimum number of accidents which might have been prevented if operating speeds were generally lower however there must have been no more than two accidents in the threeyear period which would have been possibly made more severe if traffic calming devices were in place 6 traffic diversion criteria an estimate of the diversion of traffic to other residential roadways which would result if traffic calming devices were installed on the roadway which is the subject of the complaint shall be performed traffic calming devices will not be installed if the traffic diversion would result in a traffic increase on any other residential roadway of 50 percent or more for that roadway 7 emergency access and route criteria traffic calming devices shall not be permitted on roadways which serve as a primary route for emergency vehicles defined as an average of at least five emergency vehicles a day or an emergency call or a primary access route for emergency vehicles into an area of 100 or more residential dwelling units or ten or more businesses 8 public involvement criteria the preferable method of public involvement for the installation of traffic calming devices is established homeowners association in the absence of a homeowners association or if the geographic area encompassed by the homeowners association does not cover the full impact are of the proposed traffic calming device installation a geographic area determined by the city shall be considered in the public involvement process public input may be gathered by either ballot or petition the installation of traffic calming devices must be approved ay a 75 percent majority of all dwelling units within the confines of either the homeowners association or geographic impact area as determined by the city in any case only one vote or signature on a petition per dwelling unit will be allowed  622009 limitations on placement the following shall be limitations upon the use or installation of certain traffic calming devices in the city 1 speed bumps because of their design speed bumps are generally considered inappropriate for use on the public rightofway 2 speed humps speed humps shall not be placed in the following locations a on horizontal and vertical curves or the approaches to such curves  b on a grade of five percent or greater or the approach to such grades  c adjacent to a driveway  d within 250 feet of a traffic signal  e within 50 feet of a public roadway intersection  f over or near manholes  g adjacent to fire hydrants  or h immediately upstream of drainage inlets 3 rumble strips rumble strips are not recommended for use in traffic calming situations any recommendation calling for their use shall be accompanied by a compelling reason 4 striping signage and pavement markings any recommendation to install a traffic calming device shall include recommendations for appropriate striping signage and other pavement markings to delineate the traffic calming device  622009 secs 106365106380  reserved article viii  automated traffic safety system footnotes  6  editors note  adopted  did not specify manner of inclusion  hence codification as art viii  106381106397 was at the discretion of the editor title this article shall be known and may be cited as the bessemer automated traffic safety system   5162017 findings the city council of the city of bessemer alabama makes the following findings as the basis for the undertakings on its part herein contained 1 vehicles that violate traffic control regulations and signage have been and are a dangerous problem in the city of bessemer alabama 2 studies have found that automated traffic camera enforcement in a municipal area is a highly accurate method for detecting violations of traffic control regulations and signage and is very effective in reducing the number of traffic violations and decreasing the number of traffic accidents deaths and injuries 3 current alabama law provides that failing to stop and remain stopped at a trafficcontrol signal which is emitting a steady red signal is a criminal misdemeanor current alabama law also provides that failing to abide by traffic signage or speed limits is also a criminal misdemeanor under alabama law one who commits any of these misdemeanors is subject to prosecution only if the misdemeanor was witnessed by either a duly empowered police officer or other witness who makes a verified complaint to a sworn magistrate 4 a reduction in the number of drivers exceeding speed limits and running red lights and stop signs program utilizing photographic evidence and enforcement imposition of civil fines will help promote and protect the health safety and welfare of the citizens of the city of bessemer act number 2016323 duly enacted by the legislature of alabama granted to the city of bessemer to establish a program to enforce traffic signal violations stop sign violations and speeding violations by the use of photographic evidence and the imposition of civil fines 5 by providing for the use of automated traffic cameras in traffic signal enforcement stop sign enforcement and speed limit enforcement in the city of bessemer the city council expects to decrease the occurrence in the city of traffic signal violations stop sign violations and speeding violations  5162017 definitions as used in this article the following terms shall have the following meanings city means the city of bessemer alabama city council means the governing body of the city of bessemer alabama civil violation means a violation of the provisions of this article the penalty for which violation shall be the payment of a fine the enforcement of which will not be otherwise permissible fine means the monetary amount assessed by the city of bessemer pursuant to this article for a determination of civil liability for a traffic signal violation stop sign violation or speeding violation which may include administrative hearing costs associated with the infraction intersection means the place or area where two or more streets intersect owner means the owner or owner of record of a motor vehicle as shown on the motor vehicle registration and title records of the alabama department of revenue or the analogous department or agency of another state or nation the term shall not include motor vehicles displaying dealer license plates in which event owner shall mean the person to whom the vehicle is assigned for use  nor shall the term include the owner of any stolen motor vehicle in which event owner shall mean the person who is guilty of stealing the motor vehicle and who was operating the vehicle at the time of the civil violation photographic stop sign traffic enforcement system means a system that 1 consists of a still camera system and full motion video camera system 30 frames per second or greater  and 2 is capable of producing at least two separate recorded images ie a an image of the rear of a vehicle prior to entering the intersection  and b an image of the rear of the vehicle showing the license plate photographic traffic signal enforcement system means a system that 1 consists of a still camera system and full motion video camera system 30 frames per second or greater installed to work in conjunction with an electrically operated traffic control signal  and 2 is capable of producing at least three separate recorded images ie a an image of the rear of a vehicle prior to entering the intersection on a red signal  b an image of the rear of the vehicle showing the license plate  and c an image of the rear of the vehicle in or intersection when the red signal is visible 3 all images must be synchronized to a single time source and provide the elapsed time between the first second and third photographs or digital images specified in this subparagraph b photographic vehicle speed enforcement system means a system that 1 has a mobile or fixed electronic speed enforcement system or both which is certified and in compliance with the rules of the federal communications commission  and 2 is capable of producing two or more recorded images at least one depicting the license plate attached to the rear of a vehicle being operated at a speed in excess of the applicable speed limit recorded image means an image recorded by the system depicting the rear of a vehicle which is automatically recorded as a photograph or digital image which also depicts the recorded speed date location and time of the recorded image speed limit means the established maximum speed limit on a given roadway prescribed by law speeding violation means any violation of a motor vehicle at a speed that exceeds the legal maximum speed limits set forth in or adopted pursuant to ala 197  325a170 to 325a178 inclusive or of any combination thereof  provided however that speed limits set by action of the bessemer city council if any shall supersede the limits 5162017 enforcement  procedures a the city or its designee shall mail a notice of violation by us mail to the owner of the motor vehicle which is recorded by the photographic traffic signal enforcement system photographic stop sign enforcement system or photographic vehicle speed enforcement system while committing a traffic signal violation stop sign violation or speeding violation the notice shall be sent not later than the 30th day after the date the traffic signal violation stop sign violation or speeding violation is recorded to 1 the owners address as shown on the records of the alabama department of revenue  or 2 if the vehicle is registered in another state or country to the owners address as shown on the motor vehicle registration records of the department or agency of the other state or country analogous to the alabama department of revenue b a notice of violation issued under this article shall contain the following 1 description of the violation  2 the date time and location of the violation  3 a copy of a recorded image of the vehicle  4 the amount of the fine to be imposed for the violation  5 the date by which the fine must be paid  6 a statement that the person named in the notice of violation may pay the fine in lieu of appearing at an administrative hearing  7 information that informs the person named in the notice of violation a of the right to contest the imposition of the fine in an administrative hearing  b of the manner and time in which to contest the imposition of the fine  and c that failure to pay the fine or to contest liability is an admission of liability  8 a statement that a recorded image is evidence in a proceeding for the imposition of a fine  9 in the case of a motor vehicle rental or leasing company the procedure for transferring liability to the renter or lessee and a request for the name address and drivers license number of the renter or lessee  10 a statement that failure to pay the fine within the time allowed shall result in the imposition of a late penalty not exceeding $2500  and 11 any other information deemed necessary by the city or its designee c a notice of violation under this article is presumed to have been received on the tenth day after the date the notice of violation is placed in the united states mail d a fine imposed pursuant to this article shall be paid within 30 days of the tenth day after the date the notice of violation is mailed e it shall be within the discretion of the trained technician to determine which of the recorded traffic signal violations stop sign violations and speeding violations are to be enforced based upon the quality and legibility of the recorded image  5162017 administrative adjudication hearing a an administrative hearing officer appointed by the mayor of the city is vested with the power and jurisdiction to conduct administrative hearings of civil violations provided for in this article in conducting administrative hearings of violations of this article the hearing officer shall have the powers and duties conferred by act no 2016323 of the legislature of alabama b a person who receives a notice of violation may contest the imposition of the fine by submitting a request for an administrative hearing of the civil violation in writing within 15 days of the tenth day after the date the notice of violation is mailed upon receipt of a timely request the city or its designee shall notify the person of the date and time of the administrative hearing by us mail c failure to pay a fine or to contest liability in a timely manner is an admission of liability in the full amount of the fine assessed in the notice of violation d any fine imposed pursuant to this article shall not be collected if after a hearing the administrative hearing officer appointed by the mayor of the city enters a finding of no liability e if an administrative hearing is requested the city shall have the burden of proving the traffic signal violation stop sign violation or speeding violation by a preponderance of the evidence the reliability of the photographic traffic signal enforcement system or photographic stop sign enforcement system used to produce the recorded image of the violation may be attested to by affidavit of a trained technician an affidavit of a trained technician that alleges a violation based on an inspection of the pertinent recorded image is admissible in a proceeding under this article and is evidence of the facts contained in the affidavit f the notice of violation the recorded and reproduced images of the traffic signal violation stop sign violation or speeding violation regardless of the media on which they are recorded accompanied by a certification of authenticity of a trained technician and evidence of ownership of a vehicle as shown by copies or summaries of official records shall be admissible into evidence without foundation unless the administrative hearing officer finds there is an indication of untrustworthiness in which case the city shall be given a reasonable opportunity to lay an evidentiary foundation g all other matters of evidence and procedure not specifically addressed in this article shall be subject to the rules of evidence and the rules of procedure as they apply in the small claims courts of this state except that on any petition to jefferson county circuit court for trial de novo the evidence and procedures shall be as for any civil case in the district court except as otherwise provided in this article and act no 2016323 of the legislature of alabama h a person who is found liable for a civil violation pursuant to this article after an administrative hearing or who requests a hearing and thereafter fails to appear at the time and place of the hearing is liable for administrative hearing costs and fees set out herein in addition to the amount of the fine assessed for the violation a person who is found liable for a civil violation after an administrative hearing shall pay the fine and costs within ten days of the hearing i whenever payment of a fine is owed to the city the amount of the fine as set by this article may not be increased decreased or abated by the city and the liability may be satisfied only by payment j it shall be an affirmative defense to the imposition of civil liability under this article to be proven by a preponderance of the evidence that 1 the traffic control signal was not in proper position and sufficiently visible to an ordinarily observant person  2 the operator of the motor vehicle was acting in compliance with the lawful order or direction of a police officer  3 the operator of the motor vehicle violated the instructions of the traffic control signal so as to yield the rightofway to an immediately approaching authorized emergency vehicle  4 the motor vehicle was being operated as an authorized emergency vehicle under ala 197  325a7 and 325213 and that the operator was acting in compliance with those chapters  5 the motor vehicle was stolen or being operated by a person other than the owner of the vehicle without the effective consent of the owner  6 the license plate depicted in the recorded image of the violation was a stolen plate and being displayed on a motor vehicle other than the motor vehicle for which the plate had been issued  7 the presence of ice snow unusual amounts of rain or other unusually hazardous road conditions existed that would make compliance with this article more dangerous under the circumstances than noncompliance  or 8 there was no sign installed as required by this article near the location at which the violation allegedly occurred warning that a photographic traffic signal enforcement system was being used k to establish that at the time of the violation the motor vehicle was a stolen vehicle or the license plate displayed on the motor vehicle was a stolen plate the owner must submit proof acceptable to the hearing officer that the theft of the vehicle or license plate prior to the time of the violation or promptly following the theft had been timely reported to the appropriate law enforcement agency service if service is disconnected for nonpayment bessemer electric service reserves the right to increase the deposit up to twice the average monthly bill for the actual billing location prior to reinitiation of service and service shall not be reconnected until said deposit is paid c minimum deposit for residential water customers only a minimum deposit as determined in the bessemer electric and water service rate charge and service fee schedule is required for meter sizes less than one inch for meter sizes of one inch or larger the deposit will be no less than two times the minimum deposit charge for each meter or the average estimated usage whichever is greater d minimum deposit for residential electric customers only a minimum deposit of $7500 or as determined in the bessemer electric and water service rate charge and service fee schedule whichever is greater is required for residential electric customers e for commercial customers all commercial customers will pay a twomonth deposit of the average monthly bill for the billing location as determined over the past 12month period where a billing history does not exist the deposit will be estimated based on projected energy loading or usage for the customer such deposit may be sent by separate bill or included in the customers first monthly billing if such deposit is not made at the time specified bessemer electric and water service may withhold service if service is disconnected for nonpayment bessemer electric and water service reserves the right to increase the deposit up to three times the average monthly bill for the actual billing location prior to reinitiation of service and service shall not be reconnected until said deposit is paid f deposits shall accrue interest annually at the rate if any as determined by the deposit holding account such interest shall be paid annually calculated to december 1 of each year for the time such deposit was held by the utility unless such period is less than one month said interest if any will be paid by credit to the customers account on the december billing g if any customers account is no longer in good standing and frequently becomes past due bessemer electric and water service may require an additional deposit should the customers usage increase sufficiently to warrant an additional deposit h upon disconnection or discontinuation of service the customers deposit where available including any interest accrued shall be credited to their final bill any remaining deposit balance will be returned to the forwarding address provided by the customer at time of service disconnection within approximately four to six weeks if deposit balance remains unclaimed for more than one year from service disconnection said deposit will be turned over to the office of the alabama state treasurer unclaimed property division   ii 3151988   522017 billing a meters will be read as nearly as possible the same day each month or the same day each quarter b each month will be divided into eight billing cycles and bills will be mailed within eight calendar days from the day the first account is read for that billing cycle c bills will be due no less than 15 days after bills are mailed d bills will contain current meter readings amount used amount of charges for each service the date the bill is due the amount before the late payment charge the amount of the late payment charge and the amount including the late charge e a late payment charge will be added to each bill after the due date a late payment charge of five percent on electric and ten percent on water of the current bill charged will be added to the customers current balance f payments received by mail after the due date will not be charged a late charge provided the us postmark is on or before the due date regardless as to when the payment is actually received g if the due date is on a sunday or holiday the following day will be considered a day of grace if the payment is made in the office and not in the night depository h a notice will be mailed no earlier than two business days after the due date advising the customer that their bill has not been paid this notice will advise the customer that the late charge has been added and that an additional ten days has been granted if the bill is not paid service will be discontinued such notice shall contain instructions on how to apply for a hearing if the bill is disputed or if the customer is in financial distress and unable to pay the bill i if the customer fails to respond either with payment or by notifying the utility disputing the amount of the bill or by advising the office of the customers inability to pay service will be discontinued as scheduled j if the customer disputes the amount owed or the right of bessemer electric and water service to collect or is unable to pay the bill then the customer can follow the instructions set out in section 10244 k bessemer electric and water service evaluates weather conditions daily national weather service at wwwweathergov which is a component of the national oceanic and atmospheric administration noaa and is the operating unit of the us department of commerce and in the event that the forecasted high temperature is expected to exceed 98 degrees fahrenheit f or is expected to be below 32 degrees fahrenheit f on that day bessemer electric and water service will postpone the disconnection of service of residential customers for nonpayment during such extreme weather events where disconnection is postponed due to weather conditions the postponement will not extend beyond the extreme weather condition and the customer will be billed and is responsible for any utility used during this period l customers with life threatening medical conditions may provide a letter from a medical doctor or nurse practitioner licensed to practice in the state of alabama and submit it to bessemer electric and water service documenting hisher life threatening medical condition the letter must include a signature from an attending physician or nurse practitioner affirming that the disconnection of electricity would create a medical emergency and possibly death it is the responsibility of the customer to ensure that the form is on file with the bessemer electric and water service a life threatening medical condition does not relieve a customer from its obligation to pay for electrical service including any late fees incurred or other applicable charges upon acceptance of the form by bessemer electric and water service the disconnection will be postponed for 30 days from the original scheduled disconnection date bessemer electric and water service will only grant this postponement of termination two times in a 12month period for the life threatening medical conditions if full payment of the past due amount including all late fees is not received by the end of the 30day postponement period electric or water service will be terminated on the next available date the customer will be billed and is responsible for any utility used during this period   iii 3151988   522017 account review and collection a this shall be the primary document from which specific procedures and guidelines governing all aspects of the account review and collection function of bessemer utilities are drawn and shall be the statement of basic policy which governs all bessemer utilities account review and collection activities b this policy is based on the premise that it shall be the duty and responsibility of bessemer utilities to maintain customer accounts in such a manner that the investment made in these public utility agencies owned over the years by the city may be protected and maintained in trust for all past present and future citizens and customers and in such a manner that current customers may be protected against possible inequities arising from the failure of persons to pay bills c due process shall be offered customers of bessemer utilities that both a customer collections procedure and accounts review procedure exist and will be furnished on request and that a customer can be represented by anyone of his choosing at any stage of the proceedings d the account review procedure will provide all customers of the system an opportunity to maintain utility service by entering into an agreement that within ten days after a final determination the customer will pay the amount determined unless the customer elects to use the provisions of the customer collections procedure e the customer collections procedure will provide all customers of the system an opportunity to maintain utility service by entering into and honoring a written agreement that they will keep all monthly bills current and paid in full and reduce any balance that is in arrears to zero dollars over an agreed period f failure to pay or to make arrangements to pay or to honor the arrangement to pay the bill due to bessemer utilities in a manner which will keep all monthly bills current and paid in full and reduce any balance that is in arrears to zero dollars in an agreed period will be cause after notification by the mailing of a final notice for termination of service g the accounts review procedure will provide customers of bessemer utilities adequate opportunity for an investigation hearing and review process the customer shall have the right to an informal hearing before a designated supervisor where an agreement as to the balance due on their bill cannot be reached h the customer has the right if he so requests to a formal hearing before a board of review made up of the office manager accountant and engineering assistant of the utilities or their appointed representatives it shall also offer an opportunity for the temporary maintenance of service or the temporary restoration of service to customers whose claim entitles them to consideration under this procedure such maintenance or restoration of service shall be temporary and for the term of this procedure only customers seeking such relief will agree in writing to firm conditions concerning such maintenance or temporary restoration of service before service is continued or actually restored it shall be the responsibility of the customer to produce sufficient documentation to support the possible validity of the claim i the employees of bessemer utilities are prohibited from collecting part payment except as provided in the customer collection procedures as set out in section 11053 j a daily log of all transactions and account dispositions pertinent to the account review and collection policy review shall be maintained k the accounts review procedure shall be as follows 1 this provision is to provide and guarantee each customer of bessemer electric and water service of an adequate opportunity for investigation and a due process hearing for the purpose of resolving the customers complaint it shall also offer an opportunity for temporary continuance of service or if the service has been discontinued the temporary restoration of service to customers whose claim entitles them to consideration under this procedure such restoration of service shall be temporary and for the term of this procedure only 2 when it is determined that the customer disputes the amount owed or the correctness of the bill or the accuracy of the meter reading or that their account has not been properly credited or the right of bessemer utilities to terminate his services or honor written agreements the customer will be routed to the account clerk who will first make an attempt to resolve the issue raised by the customer if the account clerk is unable to resolve the issue raised by the customer then the account clerk will grant to the customer an informal hearing 3 at the opening of the hearing the account clerk will give the customer a copy of this article and explain to the customer the procedure to be used the customer will be advised that he has the right to have his service restored if it has been discontinued or continued while the account review procedures are in progress if the customer is willing to sign an agreement concerning the continuance or restoration of service failure to sign an agreement will cause the customer to forfeit his rights to have his service continued or restored as the case may be as part of the proceedings the customer has the right to examine bessemer utilities records pertaining to that customers service if after examining the records the account clerk or the customer has a question about the reading on the meter then the hearing will be recessed to a date certain and a utilities representative will be sent to obtain a current reading the customer will be notified at the time when the representative will read the meter so the customer may be present at the appointed time the hearing will be reconvened all pertinent records including the latest reading of the meter will be available the customer may be present and represented by any one of his choosing to cross examine witnesses and present any evidence he may desire within five days of the hearing a written decision will be mailed to the customer this decision shall include a notification to the customer that he has a right to a formal hearing before a board of review and advise him of the necessary steps to invoke the review process 4 if the customer accepts the judgment of the account clerk then he will have ten days in which to pay the amount found due by the account clerk or to invoke the customer collection proceedings as set out in subsection 1 of this section if the customer fails to give notice of appeal to the account review board within five days of the decision being hand delivered or mailed paying the amount determined to be due or exercising his right under the customer collection procedure within ten days then a final notice will be sent and service terminated within five days of sending the notice 5 if the customer wishes to appeal the account clerks decision and files a notice of appeal the office manager shall set a time and date for a hearing and a notice of such hearing shall be sent to the customer the notice must be sent at least five days before the hearing within five days after the hearing a written decision shall be mailed to the customer the decision will determine the amount owed by the customer and the date by which it must be paid this will then be entered in the records of bessemer utilities 6 if the customer fails to make payments as provided in the decision or fails to exercise his rights under the customer collection procedures then a final notice shall be sent to the customer and service shall be terminated within five days of mailing the final notice   iv 3151988 customer collection procedure a if the customer is not disputing the amount owed nor the right of bessemer utilities to collect due bills line employees including cashiers and customer complaint clerks will deal directly with each customers collection inquiry the employee will determine specifically the customers problem and if possible provide the appropriate relief under this policy and guidelines as provided by the utilities manager and enter into a written agreement with the customer at that time the line employee must maintain adequate records on each such transaction all agreements with the customer to maintain service shall be executed in writing routed to the supervisor of the service desk for review filed and appropriate interaction with the data processing section taken a daily log of all inquiries transactions and account dispositions shall be maintained by each employee and routed at the end of each working day to the supervisor of the service desk the same basic process shall apply to longterm agreements exceeding one month in all cases the customer will pay monthly bills in full and an agreed portion of the arrears each month b if the customer fails to make payments as provided in the agreement then a final notice shall be sent to the customer and service terminated within five days c the circumstances under which the line employees must refer the customer to the supervisor of the service desk for review and decision on inquiry by the customer includes any case in which a customer 1 reveals crt search and other indicators that he may not be either willing or able to enter into a longterm written agreement to pay current bills and arrears in a manner consistent with the declining account balance policy 2 claims special circumstances prevent him from entering into a written agreement 3 discloses that a total dollar amount in excess of $30000 is owed 4 may be a verifiable hardship case 5 is in an uncontrollable emotional state d if the customer is referred to the supervisor of the service desk or his designated representative the supervisor will listen to the customers claim establish a written record of what the customer is alleging and determine whether it is within the supervisors authority to make a final disposition of the inquiry whether it is a situation which requires further investigation whether in fact it is a dispute over the amount of the bill or a customer relations dilemma rather than a collection matter if it is determined that it is other than a collection matter then the written record of each transaction will be routed to the account clerk e if the issues raised by the customer fall within the collection procedures guideline and an agreement cannot be worked out with the customer then an informal hearing will be conducted by the supervisor of the service desk and within five days of the hearing a written decision will be handed to or mailed to the customer as part of the decision the supervisor will determine whether or not the customer is entitled to an extension and if so the amount to be paid by the customer on the arrearage each month and will advise the customer that he has a right to a final review process and shall be informed of the nature of such final review process the customer shall have five days from the day the decision is mailed or the decision is personally delivered to him by the supervisor to invoke the appeals process to the review board if the customer fails to invoke the appeals process it shall be construed as consent to the decision of the supervisor and the decision of the supervisor will be entered in the same manner as an agreement and the customer will be expected to pay as directed by the supervisor f if the customer fails to make payments as provided in the agreement with the supervisor or the supervisors determination as the case may be then a final notice shall be sent to the customer and service terminated within five days g in the event the customer wishes to appeal the supervisors decision and files a notice of appeal the office manager shall set a time and date for a hearing and a notice of such hearing shall be sent to the customer the notice must be sent at least five days before the hearing within five days after the hearing a written decision shall be mailed to the customer the decision will determine whether the customer is entitled to an extension and the amount to be paid by the customer on the arrearage each month this will then be entered in the records of the bessemer utilities and the customer notified of his schedule of payments h if the customer fails to make payments as provided in the decision then a final notice shall be sent to the customer and service terminated within five days   iv 3151988 diversion of water or electricity  determination  assessment of penalty  posting of notice  hearing a it shall be unlawful for anyone water in any manner b on an account where service has been terminated or discontinued if the service is turned on by someone other than an authorized employee of bessemer utilities or someone does one or more of the prohibited acts as set out in subsection a of this section the service will be immediately discontinued at this location without notice and steps shall be taken to prevent the unauthorized restoration of service a penalty will be charged against the location for the unlawful act and service will not be restored until this penalty and the other charges provided in this article are paid c on an active account if someone does one or more of the prohibited acts as set out in subsection a of this section the employees of bessemer utilities shall immediately remove the device and preserve it for evidence install a new meter and seal it with locking devices and give notice at the location that within five business days a hearing will be held before the accounts review board as provided in section 11052 d it shall be the duty of the accounts review board to determine if there has been a diversion of water or electricity if this is determined in the affirmative the accounts review board will determine if the person responsible for the location as reflected in the records of bessemer utilities knew of the diversion or benefited from it if this is found in the affirmative then the accounts review board will determine if service is to be immediately discontinued or continued and on what conditions if the accounts review board determines that there has been a diversion and that the customer of bessemer utilities knew of the diversion or benefited from it then the board is hereby authorized to determine the value of the water or electricity diverted and may assess this against the customer or account and are further authorized to assess a penalty for an amount within the discretion of the board e the posting of the following notice on the entrance of the customers residence or business as the case may be will be sufficient service the notice will advise the customer of the date and time of the hearing that they may be represented by counsel that the hearing could result in the termination of their utility service a determination being made by the review board of the amount of water or electricity diverted and their being charged for this plus a penalty and a new deposit and fees for reconnecting the service f the amount of any penalty charge new deposit or other fee listed in this section shall be established by the appendix a  subdivisions subdivision regulations adopted by the city of bessemer planning and zoning commission footnotes  1  editors note printed herein are the subdivision regulations as adopted by the city council on  amendments to these regulations are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions the absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original regulations obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation for stylistic purposes headings and catchlines have been made uniform and the same system of capitalization as appears in the ordinances has been used where a section has been amended or repealed by a later provision only the current language has been printed additions made for purposes of clarity are indicated by brackets general provisions title these regulations shall hereafter be known cited and referred to as the subdivision regulations of the city of bessemer alabama authority under the provisions of title 11 subtitle 2 chapter 52 articles 2 and 3 of the alabama 1975 ala 197  115230115236 and 115250115254 these following regulations governing the subdivision and development of land are hereby adopted by the bessemer planning and zoning commission at a meeting on  jurisdiction 1 on and after  these subdivision regulations shall apply to all subdivisions and development of land as defined herein located within the corporate limits of the city of bessemer 2 no land shall be subdivided within the corporate limits of the city of bessemer until a the subdivider or his agent has submitted the required plats and plans to the planning and zoning commission and b approval of all plats and plans including approval of the final plat by the planning and zoning commission and c the approved final plat is recorded with the office of the judge of probate jefferson county 3 no building permit or certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any lot parcel plot of land or building site which was created by subdivision after the effective date of and not in conformity with the provisions of these subdivision regulations and no excavation of land or construction of any public or private improvements shall take place or be commenced except in conformity with these regulations purpose the purpose and intent of these regulations is to establish objective citywide standards for public improvements and the subdivision of land within the city of bessemer these regulations are based upon the following elements 1 proper subdivision design criteria 2 the impact of development upon adjacent property 3 the definition of public and private development responsibilities 4 concern for the health safety and welfare of the entire city 5 encouragement of an orderly and efficient development pattern 6 coordination with other applicable ordinances and plans administration enforcement violations and penalties 1 it shall be the duty of the city of bessemer building official to enforce these regulations and to enforce these regulations and to bring to the attention of the bessemer city attorney any violations or lack of compliance herewith 2 no owner or agent of the owner of any parcel of land located in a proposed subdivision shall transfer or sell any such parcel before a final plat of such subdivision has been approved by the planning and zoning commission in accordance with the provisions of these regulations and filed with the judge of probate jefferson county the description of metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer shall not exempt the transaction from these penalties 3 the penalty for transferring a lot in an unapproved subdivision shall be five hundred dollars for each lot or parcel so transferred or sold the city of bessemer may enjoin such transfer or sale or agreement by action for injunction brought in any court or equity jurisdiction or may recover the same penalty by a civil action in any court or of competent jurisdiction conflict with other laws whenever the provisions of these regulations impose more restrictive standards than are required in or under any other ordinance the regulations herein contained shall prevail whenever the provisions of any other ordinance requires more restrictive standards than are required herein the requirements of such regulations shall prevail seperability if any section clause or portion of these regulations shall be held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unconstitutional such findings shall not affect any other section clause or portion of these regulations variances 1 hardship where the planning and zoning commission finds that unusual hardship may result from strict compliance with these regulations it may approve variances to these regulations so that substantial justice may be done provided that such variation shall not have the effect of nullifying the intent or purpose of these regulations 2 conditions for variance the planning and zoning commission shall not approve variances unless it shall make findings based upon the evidence that presented to it in each specific case that a the granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public safety health or welfare or injurious to other property b the conditions upon which the request for a variance is based are unique to the property for which the variance is sought and are not applicable generally to other property c because of the particular physical surroundings shape or topographical conditions of the property involved a particular hardship to the owner would result as distinguished from a mere inconvenience if the strict letter of these regulations are carried out 3 petition a petition for such variance shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time when the preliminary plat is filed for the consideration by the planning and zoning commission the petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and all of the facts relied upon by the petitioner 4 documentation any variance thus authorized shall be entered in writing in the minutes of the planning and zoning commission with the reason which justified the departure to be set forth amendment these regulations may be amended after notice and public hearing in the same manner as prescribed by law for their original adoption assurance for completion of improvements 1 generally the subdivider shall be responsible for the provision of all required improvements to the subdivision this may be accomplished by either the full installation of all required improvements by the subdivider at the time the final plat is submitted to the planning and zoning commission or by the provision of a financial guarantee of performance 2 financial guarantee of performance the guarantee of performance by the subdivider shall be in the form of a subdivision improvement bond or an a certificate of deposit and shall meet the following requirements a bond or certificate of deposit must be approved by the city engineer and building official b bond or cd must be in an amount not less than 200 percent of the total cost to cover the installation of all required roads paving and utilities and fees encountered in the completion of improvements 3 failure to complete work if within twelve months after filing said bond the subdivider has not completed all necessary improvements or in the opinion of the planning and zoning commission said improvements have not been satisfactorily installed the bond shall be used by the city to complete the improvements in a satisfactory manner or the city may take such steps as may be necessary to require performance under the bond 4 guarantee against faulty material the planning and zoning commission may require a maintenance bond for five years for street construction maintenance and one year for sewer lines and other facilities if there is reasonable doubt concerning the stability or proper construction of any improvement required herein this bond shall be made in cash or by a surety company authorized to do business in the state of alabama vacation of plat or map 1 any plat or map whether or not executed and recorded as provided in these regulations may be vacated by the owner his executor administrator or guardian of the lands at any time before the sale of any lot therein by a written instrument declaring the same to be vacated executed acknowledged and recorded in like manner as conveyances of land which declaration being duly recorded shall operate to destroy the force and effect of the recording of the plat or map so vacated and to divest all public rights in the streets alleys and public grounds and all dedications laid out or described in such plat or map 2 when lots have been sold the plat or map may be vacated in the manner herein provided by all the owners of lots in such plat or map joining in the execution of such writing definitions plat by the planning and zoning commission shall not constitute acceptance by the public of the dedication of any street or other public way or ground after approval of the final plat and the construction of streets shown thereon the city engineer may recommend to the city council that it accept these streets as public roads and other ways or grounds as public facilities and take over their perpetual maintenance design standards for streets inspection 1 the city engineer shall approve the proposed grades type of paving size of drainage structures and any or all other engineering problems involved therein before a subdivider commences to grade or pave streets within a subdivision 2 before construction of streets the city engineer shall be notified no less than 24 hours in advance of any phase of operation to be started 3 the base shall be inspected and installed under the direction of the city engineer 4 no paving shall be installed until the base is approved 5 no paving shall be installed until approval is given as to type of paving and materials used 6 in cases in which the city engineer has reasonable doubt concerning the stability or proper construction of any streets he may require that after installation of the binder course that the seal course of bituminous pavement be delayed for a period of minimum of six months topography and arrangement 1 all streets shall be designed along contour elevations which will result in minimum grades and greatest visibility whenever practicable with consideration given to the anticipated use of the land grades of streets shall conform as closely as possible to the original topography 2 the proposed street layout shall be made according to sound land planning principles for the type of development proposed 3 local and collector streets shall be laid out to discourage use by to permit efficient drainage and utility systems and to require the minimum number of streets necessary to provide convenient and safe access to property 4 existing streets and rightofway which are proposed to be retained shall be incorporated into the street system so as not to cause hazardous conditions 5 proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided unless prevented by topography of other physical conditions or unless in the opinion of the city engineer and planning and zoning commission such extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with the existing layout or the most advantageous future development of adjacent tracts 6 where a proposed subdivision has no frontage on an existing public road or public rightofway the subdivider must provide and dedicate to the city a suitable rightofway for ingress and egress this connecting road becomes part of the street system of the proposed subdivision and is subject to all regulations regarding streets 7 the arrangement of streets shall provide for the continuation of principal streets between adjacent properties when such continuation is necessary for convenient movement of traffic effective fire protection or for efficient provision of utilities if the adjacent property is undeveloped and the street must be a deadend street temporarily the rightofway shall be extended to the property line a temporary culdesac turnabout shall be provided on all temporary deadend streets with the notation on the subdivision plat that land outside the normal street rightofway shall revert to abuttors whenever the street is continued the planning and zoning commission may limit the length of temporary deadend streets in accordance with the design standards of these regulations 8 where a road does not extend to the boundary of the subdivision and its continuation is not required by the planning and zoning commission for access to adjoining property its terminus shall normally not be nearer to such boundary than 50 feet however the planning and zoning commission may require the reservation of an appropriate easement to accommodate drainage facilities pedestrian traffic or utilities a culdesac turnaround shall be provided at the end of a permanent deadend street in accordance with the design standards of these regulations for convenience to traffic and more effective police and fire protection permanent deadend streets shall in general be limited to 750 in length intersections 1 streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles and in no case at an angle of less than 75 degrees an easement radius may be required by the city engineer for intersections having an interior angle of less than 90 degrees 2 intersections involving more than four basic street legs or approaches shall be prohibited merging lanes deceleration lanes y intersections and traffic circles are not included in this prohibition but are considered as being parts of one street leg or approach 3 opposing intersections shall be placed opposite each other where practical or placed at a minimum of 150 feet apart except where the intersected street has separated dual drives without median breaks at either intersection 4 minimum curb radius at all intersections shall be at least 15 feet unless a different figure is expressly approved by the city engineer because of special topographical considerations or sound engineering practices 5 intersections should be planned and located to provide as much sight distance as possible in achieving a safe highway design as a minimum there should be sufficient sight distance for the driver on the local or collector street to cross an arterial without requiring approaching traffic to reduce speed 6 the vertical alignment in the intersection area should be as flat as possible where the grade of any street at the approach to an intersection exceeds three percent a leveling area shall be provided having not greater than a three percent grade for a distance of fifty feet from the intersection of the street centerline street rightofway widths 1 the planning and zoning commission shall determine the classification of city streets 2 minimum widths of rightofway are as follows street classification minimum rightofway width in feet alley 20 local 50 collector 50 arterial or commercialindustrial 80 culdesac 50 3 subdivisions that adjoin existing streets shall dedicate additional rightofway to meet the minimum rightofway width requirements a the entire rightofway shall be provided where any part of the subdivision is located on both sides of the existing streets b when the subdivision is located on only one side of an existing street a sufficient amount of rightofway shall be provided by the applicant in order to meet the rightofway requirements street pavement widths minimum pavement widths are as follows street classification minimum pavement width lane alley 10 feet local 24 feet collector 24 feet arterial or commercialindustrial 24 feet culdesac 40 feet radius street grades and vertical alignment 1 the grades for all streets shall not exceed 15 percent or be less than one percent 2 the maximum street grade is as follows street classification minimum rightofway width alley 8% local 15% collector 12% arterial or commercialindustrial 8% 3 grades approaching intersections shall not exceed three percent for a distance of 50 feet from the intersection of the street centerline 4 vertical curves shall be used at all changes of grade exceeding one percent and shall be designed with equal tangents in order to avoid hazardous profiles 5 proper drainage shall be provided at the low point in vertical curves cross slope 1 on streets in tangent alignment the high point of the road shall be at the center of the pavement 2 on typical asphalt treated seal coats the cross slope from the center line shall be 14 per foot on other types of surfacing the cross slope shall be determined by the city engineer horizontal curvature for streets 1 all streets shall have a minimum radius of curvature of 250 feet super elevation 1 super elevation shall normally be used on curves to aid the vehicle in negotiating the curve 2 the maximum rate of super elevation cross slope shall not exceed 8 percent the centerline of the street shall normally be used for the axis of rotation 3 care shall be taken to avoid drainage pockets in the low points of the super elevation 4 the transition from a crown slope to super elevation shall be determined by standard engineering practice sight distance 1 stopping a the minimum stopping sight distance is the distance required by the driver of the vehicle to a complete stop after an object in the street ahead becomes visible stopping sight distance is measured from the drivers eyes which are assumed to be 375 feet above the street surface to an object 6 inches high on the street surface ahead b the minimum stopping sight distances for design of all twolane streets shall be determined by the city engineer design speed mph minimum stopping sight distance feet 25 175 30 200 35 230 40 275 45 310 50 350 55 415 2 passing a passing sight distance is the minimum sight distance that enables a driver to safely pass another vehicle without interfering with oncoming traffic traveling at the designed speed the sight distance available for passing is the longest distance at which a driver whose eyes are 375 feet above the street can see the top of an object 45 feet above the street surface ahead b the minimum passing sight distance shall be determined by the city engineer design speed mph minimum stopping sight distance feet 25 900 30 1100 35 1300 40 1500 50 1800 55 1900 alleys 1 alleys may be required in commercial and industrial districts to facilitate access to parking loading and service points 2 alleys are not permitted in residential districts except when the planning and zoning commission determines that special conditions warrant a secondary means of access road surfacing 1 applicability a permanent type paving shall be applied to all streets in a proposed subdivision 2 subgrade a the subgrade shall be thoroughly compacted and shaped prior to application of the base b the subgrade where portland cement paving is to be used shall be brought to a firm and unyielding condition with a uniform density of 95 percent proctor c the city engineer shall have the subgrade roll tested at the developers cost and approved prior to base placement 3 base a the city engineer shall determine if a special base is required for portland cement concrete surfaced streets b the base materials for asphalt surfaced roads shall be approved as to mixture and durability by the city engineer c the base material shall be spread without segregation in a loose maximum eightinch lift and shall be compacted by vibratory steel wheel rollers or other approved rollers to a maximum density of 95 percent proctor additional depth of base material may be required because of anticipated traffic d the base shall be inspected and installed under the direction of the city engineer and no surfacing shall be installed until the base has been approved by the city engineer 4 asphalt surfacing a a minimum of a two inch hot bituminous plant mixed binder layer shall be placed on the approved base b a minimum of a 112 hot bituminous wearing surface shall be placed on the approved binder layer after approval of the city engineer c a triple surface treatment type paving bituminous surface treatment may be used in lieu of plant mix binder and seal when approved by the city engineer the type and rate of application for the prime seal and aggregate shall be approved by the city engineer and shall conform to the latest edition of alabama state highway department regulations and specifications 5 portland cement concrete paving a a minimum of sixinch portland cement concrete pavement without reinforcement shall be constructed in one course on a prepared sub grade and base if required after approval by the city engineer b installation shall meet the requirements for strength surface finish and joints as determined by the city engineer curb and gutter valley gutter sidewalks 1 the city engineer shall approve the location of curb and gutter valley gutter and sidewalks 2 curb and gutter and valley gutter shall be constructed of portland cement concrete constructed on a prepared sub grade and shall conform to the crosssections depicted in appendix 1c 3 sidewalks when required shall be a minimum of four feet wide in residential and eight feet wide in commercial areas the crosssection for a sidewalk is located in appendix 1c 4 installation of curb and gutter valley gutter and sidewalks shall meet the requirements for strength surface finish and joints as determined by the city engineer 5 sidewalks shall meet the requirements of the latest ada laws driveway access 1 applications for all new accesses to streets within the city shall be made to the city engineer the proposed location width drainage structure traffic condition site distance and surfacing shall be included in the access application 2 entrances shall be located at points affording maximum sight distances and minimum grades entrances shall not be less than 10 feet no more than 20 feet width measured at the rightofway line entrances shall be located so that the curb openings are a minimum of five feet from the nearest edge of a street drainage inlet and 50 feet from the corner radius more restrictive requirements may be required by the city engineer for commercial and industrial entrances the crosssection for a standard driveway turnout is included in appendix 1c 3 commercial and industrial entrances shall not be more than 35 feet or less than 24 feet in width measured at the rightofway line the radius to increase the opening shall not be less than 15 but not more than 25 feet larger radius to accommodate truck traffic may be required by the city engineer the distance between openings shall be a minimum of 150 feet and the distance opening from corner radius shall be 50 feet street names and signs 1 street names subdivision names and
